awd_titl_txt: Exposure Assessment of Emerging and Fugitive Contaminants: Rapid Screening of Plant Uptake and Translocation
awd_abstract_narration:
1606036
Burken

Increased production and use of man-made chemicals have benefited development, and, human welfare greatly, including unprecedented food production and increasing world-wide standard of living. However the benefit gained has the unintended consequence of increasing ubiquity and diversity of emerging compounds in our biosphere. Society is shortening the water cycle via water reuse and reclamation while advancements in organic molecule design, such as advanced pharmaceuticals and industrial compounds, introduce new potential contaminants at an ever-increasing pace. This proposal describes a high throughput screening, tiered approach to efficiently assess plant uptake and translocation of emerging and fugitive compounds. Understanding the uptake and distribution from a physicochemical perspective will advance knowledge of emerging and fugitive compound fate in plant systems.

To achieve the goal of high throughput screening, in silico (using computers) tools will be developed to predict plant uptake from physicochemical properties. In silico predictions will be validated using agronomic plants subjected to specific emerging and fugitive compounds spanning a broad chemical space. To advance knowledge of transport through the plant vascular systems after uptake, poly-parameter linear free energy relationships will be developed to predict fate of the diverse emerging and fugitive compounds in plant tissues (e.g., lignin). From individual poly-parameter linear free energy relationships, a composite partitioning model will be developed to better elucidate distribution within vascular plants, and to offer insight to emerging and fugitive compound fate in food compartments such as edible stalks, fruits and grains. Fundamental knowledge will advance in several ways. First, single-parameter prediction of emerging and fugitive compound uptake are inaccurate for polar compounds, as chemical space covers multiple dimension. 5-dimensional partitioning poly-parameter linear free energy relationships will be parameterized using high quality data. Second, the in silico predictive tools integrate fundamental chemical and biological understanding, beyond single-parameter relationships or generic box models. Third, a standardized approach to predict and measure emerging and fugitive compounds translocation by plants will increase the value of future research. The tiered approach combines multidisciplinary knowledge to generate a holistic picture of chemical transport and fate in vascular plants, particularly relating to food. Increasing knowledge on organic molecule uptake and translocation in plants will widely impact science and engineering disciplines, including: a) predicting crop uptake of pollutants from irrigation waters, b) though phytoremediation to remove contaminants from the subsurface, and, c) guiding the use of plants as biosensors of subsurface contamination in phyto-forensics. All three approaches protect human health. Agrochemical development and fundamental plant biology will also benefit from the advanced tools to understand and predict organic molecule transport, including plant hormones and community signaling. Given recent breakthroughs that elucidate similarities in transmembrane transport in roots to mammalian intestinal membranes and the blood-brain barrier, the long term merit could be tremendous to many fields. The proposed platform forecasts transport of proposed compounds, many destined to be future emerging and fugitive compounds. Broadly stated, knowledge resulting from this endeavor will address critical societal and health issues, many related to water-food interactions. Society needs to be more proactive to protect human health as human interactions shorten the water cycle, potentially funneling contaminants into and potentially up the food chain. The findings will be incorporated into numerous outreach efforts with a variety of hands-on demos and media-based examples that appeal to multiple levels of education and a variety of citizenry. All efforts rely on familiarity of plants to convey larger messages of health and pollutant impacts. This work directly translates to education platforms and can benefit both contamination assessments and safety of urban gardening in blighted urban areas, where increased exposure potential exists. Overall, society needs better knowledge on pollutant entry to global food supplies to avoid instances where widespread chemical use results in global distribution decades before a pollutant is noted as emerging.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

por.por_cntn:
Better understanding of the transport of environmental pollutants into plants also provides insight into transport in different trophic levels and in mammalian systems. Using novel analytic chemistry methods to assess transmembrane migration into plant roots and vascular transport in plants generated data on how specific organic molecules transport in plants. The unique data were used in new artificial intelligence (AI) approaches to research new poly-parameter models and insight into the complex plant-contaminant interactions. The intellectual merit benefits are notable in multiple areas, with noteworthy impacts.

The analytic chemistry advancements have specific advantages rapid screening for organic contaminants in plant tissues, with application for screening food for organic pollutants.  High-throughput methods were developed for a wide range of physiochemical properties of organic molecules. Compounds tested ranged from large-molecule, hydrophobic compounds to small-molecule, highly volatile compounds. The analytic methods are also environmental-friendly and more sustainable from a resource standpoint, being solvent-free and requiring limited time for analysis. These ground-breaking methods can be advanced in further research for greater benefit to fields of environmental chemistry and .

The environmental and public health benefits are also notable, with new insight to identifying pollutant plumes and understanding potential exposure pathways.  Use of the analysis and understanding of pollutant uptake efficiency can be used in phytoforensic evaluation to delineate subsurface contaminant presence and distribution of environmental pollutants through sampling of above-ground plant tissues. As plants have an intimate connection to the subsurface media and use energy of evapotranspiration to draw groundwater to their root systems, they are natural extractors of groundwater constituents. While extracting water and nutrients, organic contaminants are also drawn to the root interface, and many can cross the root membrane with varying efficiency. This project further elucidated that efficiency for new classes of organic contaminants and generated new data and knowledge on the physicochemical properties that controls the transmembrane transport.  Using advanced artificial intelligence tools, this complex data was evaluated for the gain of new, pioneering knowledge on poly-parameter modeling of the uptake. The advancement of AI techniques for complex environment problems was also a notable intellectual contribution, combining with other approaches and the current publications offer new methods that can be applied to future complex environmental systems.  

The impacts for the broader society also have profound potential. The tools generated can help identify and mitigate polluted environments in brownfields and impoverished communities, aiding in efficient investment and re-development. The science and technology advancement also generates opportunity for future scientists and engineers to advance the knowledge base generated in this endeavor.  

This exclusive combination of data and AI data evaluation revealed a unique relationship of transmembrane migration plants and mammalian systems to reveal that plants can be used in assessing potential human exposure, particularly for contaminated food systems. As water cycles are tightening and water reuse is prevalent in agriculture, the findings have specific application to assessing food security for emerging and fugitive contaminants. The knowledge gained can raise awareness to potential plant uptake and human exposure of organic molecules before compounds are mass produced and also allow testing in plant systems as surrogates for mammalian exposure testing to avoid future health and environmental misfortunes and tragedies.  

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2021
Modified by: Joel G Burken

Images (1 of )
  • Pollutant transport into plants was analogous to organic molecule transport in mammalian systems, as investigated for pharmaceutical transport in the human body. Transport through the blood-brain barrier based on physio-chemical properties was most similar to plant root transfer.
    Joann Stiritz, Missouri S&T
    Public Domain
    Joel G Burken
    Plants are like our brain
  • Multiple sources of pollutants have the potential to impact pollutant content vegetation and the food quality as a prominent part of the human exposome. The NN predicted the TSCF with improved accuracy compared to mechanistic models.
    Image by Majid Bagheri
    Copyrighted
